easy_general.text:
Fort Pitt is a name that can refer to many different places and events. Here are some of them:

Saskatchewan, Canada:
Fort Pitt Farms Christian Community, a group of people who are called Hutterites
Battle of Fort Pitt, a fight that happened in 1885 during a time called the North-West Rebellion
Fort Pitt Provincial Park, a park that used to be a trading post for the Hudson's Bay Company and is now a special place for history

Kent, England:
Fort Pitt Grammar School, a school for kids
Fort Pitt, Kent, a fort that was built a long time ago

Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA:
Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania), a fort that was built where Pittsburgh is now
Fort Pitt (Amtrak), a train that used to go between Pittsburgh and Altoona
Fort Pitt Blockhouse, a building that helped protect Fort Pitt
Fort Pitt Boulevard, a street
Fort Pitt Brewing Company, a company that made beer from 1906 to 1957
Fort Pitt Bridge, a bridge
Fort Pitt Elementary School, a school for kids
Fort Pitt Foundry, a place where old weapons were made
Fort Pitt Hornets, a team that played ice hockey
Fort Pitt Incline, a train that used to go up and down a hill
Fort Pitt Museum, a place to learn about history
Fort Pitt Regiment, a soccer team
Siege of Fort Pitt, a fight that happened in 1763 during a time called Pontiac's War
Treaty of Fort Pitt, a deal that was made in 1778 between the United States and a group called the Lenape
Fort Pitt Tunnel, a tunnel that goes underground

adult_non_technical.text:
"Fort Pitt is a name that has been used in different places like Saskatchewan, Canada, England, and the United States. Here's what it refers to:

In Saskatchewan, Canada, there's a community called Fort Pitt Farms, which is a group of people called Hutterites who live together and share their lives. There was also a battle called the Battle of Fort Pitt that happened during the 1885 North-West Rebellion. There's a park called Fort Pitt Provincial Park that was named after a Hudson's Bay Company trading post and is now considered a National Historic Site.

In Kent, England, there's a grammar school called Fort Pitt Grammar School. There's a fort that was built during the Napoleonic Wars called Fort Pitt, Kent.

In Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA, there's a fort called Fort Pitt that was built on the land where Pittsburgh is today. There was also a train called Fort Pitt that used to run between Pittsburgh and Altoona. There's a structure called Fort Pitt Blockhouse that was built to support Fort Pitt. There's a street called Fort Pitt Boulevard. There was a brewery called Fort Pitt Brewing Company that operated from 1906 to 1957. There's a bridge called Fort Pitt Bridge. There's an elementary school called Fort Pitt Elementary School. There's a historic armory called Fort Pitt Foundry. There was a former hockey team called Fort Pitt Hornets. There's a former funicular railroad called Fort Pitt Incline. There's a museum called Fort Pitt Museum. There was a soccer club called Fort Pitt Regiment. There was also an event called the Siege of Fort Pitt that happened in 1763 during Pontiac's War. There was a treaty called the Treaty of Fort Pitt that was signed in 1778 between the United States and the Lenape people. There's also a tunnel called Fort Pitt Tunnel."

adult_technical.text:
The term "Fort Pitt" can refer to various locations and entities across different regions, including Canada, England, and the United States. Here is a comprehensive overview of these different references:

1. Saskatchewan, Canada:
   - Fort Pitt Farms Christian Community: A Hutterite group located in Saskatchewan.
   - Battle of Fort Pitt: A significant event during the 1885 North-West Rebellion.
   - Fort Pitt Provincial Park: A National Historic Site named after a former Hudson's Bay Company trading post.

2. Kent, England:
   - Fort Pitt Grammar School: A grammar school in Kent.
   - Fort Pitt, Kent: A Napoleonic-era fort in Kent.

3. Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA:
   - Fort Pitt (Pennsylvania): A fort on the site of present-day Pittsburgh.
   - Fort Pitt (Amtrak): A former train that operated between Pittsburgh and Altoona.
   - Fort Pitt Blockhouse: A structure built in support of Fort Pitt.
   - Fort Pitt Boulevard: A street in Pittsburgh.
   - Fort Pitt Brewing Company: A brewing company that operated from 1906 to 1957.
   - Fort Pitt Bridge: A bridge in Pittsburgh.
   - Fort Pitt Elementary School: An elementary school in Pittsburgh.
   - Fort Pitt Foundry: A historic armory.
   - Fort Pitt Hornets: A former ice hockey team.
   - Fort Pitt Incline: A former funicular railroad.
   - Fort Pitt Museum: A museum in Pittsburgh.
   - Fort Pitt Regiment: A soccer club.
   - Siege of Fort Pitt: An event in 1763 during Pontiac's War.
   - Treaty of Fort Pitt: A 1778 treaty between the United States and the Lenape people.
   - Fort Pitt Tunnel: A tunnel in Pittsburgh.

The term "Fort Pitt" plays a significant role in the history, culture, and infrastructure of these regions.

samples.title: East Williston, Florida
samples.original_text:
East Williston is a census-designated place (CDP) in Levy County, Florida, United States. The population was 694 at the 2010 census.

Geography
East Williston is located at  (29.389034, -82.419488).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 966 people, 344 households, and 245 families residing in the CDP.  The population density was 310.6 people per square mile (119.9/km2).  There were 381 housing units at an average density of 122.5/sq mi (47.3/km2).  The racial makeup of the CDP was 12.42% White, 83.75% African American, 0.21% Native American, 1.14% from other races, and 2.48% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.38% of the population.

There were 344 households, out of which 35.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 29.1% were married couples living together, 36.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 28.5% were non-families. 23.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.81 and the average family size was 3.32.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 31.2% under the age of 18, 12.1% from 18 to 24, 27.6% from 25 to 44, 17.6% from 45 to 64, and 11.5% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 31 years. For every 100 females, there were 75.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 75.5 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $23,882, and the median income for a family was $28,152. Males had a median income of $26,589 versus $17,981 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $14,085.  About 29.4% of families and 28.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 41.7% of those under age 18 and 35.1% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Levy County, Florida
Census-designated places in Florida

samples.title: Mercurius (disambiguation)
samples.original_text:
Mercurius may refer to:

Mythology and fiction
 Mercury (mythology) (Latin: Mercurius), a Roman god
 Mercurius, the demon from the German fairy tale "The Spirit in the Bottle"
 The OZ-13MSX2 Mercurius, a mobile suit appearing in the anime Mobile Suit Gundam Wing

People
 Saint Mercurius (died 250), Christian saint and a martyr
 Pope John II (died 535), whose given name was Mercurius
 Mercurius Oxoniensis (1914–2003), pen-name of the British historian Hugh Trevor-Roper
 Mercurius of Transylvania, voivode of Transylvania

Other uses
 Mercurius (crater), a crater on the Moon
 Mercurius (trade union), a former Dutch trade union
 Mercurius (Sweden), a Swedish Investment company that part bought Coloroll

See also
 Mercury (disambiguation) (Latin: Mercurius)
 Meconium, the earliest stool of a mammalian infant

easy_general.text:
"Mercurius is a name that can refer to different things. Here are some examples:

Mythology and Fiction:
- The Roman god Mercury, who is also known as Mercurius in Latin. He was the god of communication, trade, and commerce.
- A demon from a German fairy tale called "The Spirit in the Bottle."
- A robot from a Japanese anime called Mobile Suit Gundam Wing.

People:
- Saint Mercurius, a Christian saint who died in 250.
- Pope John II, who died in 535.
- Mercurius Oxoniensis, a pen name used by a British historian named Hugh Trevor-Roper.
- Mercurius of Transylvania, a ruler of Transylvania.

Other Uses:
- A crater on the Moon.
- A former Dutch trade union.
- A Swedish investment company that bought part of a company called Coloroll.

See Also:
- Mercury, a planet in our solar system.
- Meconium, the first poop of a baby."

adult_non_technical.text:
Mercurius is a name that can refer to different things:

Mythology and Fiction:
- The Roman god Mercury, who is also known as Mercurius in Latin.
- A demon from a German fairy tale called "The Spirit in the Bottle."
- A robot character in the anime Mobile Suit Gundam Wing.

People:
- Saint Mercurius, a Christian saint and martyr who died in 250.
- Pope John II, who died in 535, and whose real name was a man named Mercurius.
- A British historian named Hugh Trevor-Roper, who used the pen-name Mercurius Oxoniensis.
- A voivode of Transylvania named Mercurius.

Other Uses:
- A crater on the Moon named Mercurius.
- A former Dutch trade union called Mercurius.
- A Swedish investment company named Mercurius, which bought part of a company called Coloroll.

See Also:
- Mercury, the planet closest to the Sun, which is also known as Mercurius in Latin.
- Meconium, the first stool of a newborn baby.

adult_technical.text:
The term "Mercurius" can refer to various entities across different domains, including mythology, fiction, people, and other uses. Here is a comprehensive overview of these references:

Mythology and Fiction:
1. Mercury (mythology) (Latin: Mercurius): A Roman god associated with commerce, communication, and travel.
2. Mercurius, the demon from the German fairy tale "The Spirit in the Bottle": A malevolent entity from traditional German folklore.
3. The OZ-13MSX2 Mercurius, a mobile suit from the anime Mobile Suit Gundam Wing: A fictional character in the popular anime series.

People:
1. Saint Mercurius (died 250): A Christian saint and martyr.
2. Pope John II (died 535): Whose given name was Mercurius.
3. Mercurius Oxoniensis (1914–2003): The pen-name of the British historian Hugh Trevor-Roper.
4. Mercurius of Transylvania: A voivode of Transylvania.

Other Uses:
1. Mercurius (crater): A crater on the Moon.
2. Mercurius (trade union): A former Dutch trade union.
3. Mercurius (Sweden): A Swedish investment company that partially acquired Coloroll.

See Also:
1. Mercury (disambiguation) (Latin: Mercurius): A broader term encompassing all the various references to Mercurius.
2. Meconium: The earliest stool of a mammalian infant.

samples.title: Humboldt, Illinois
samples.original_text:
Humboldt is a village in Coles County, Illinois, United States. At the 2020 census, its population was 361. It is part of the Charleston-Mattoon Micropolitan Statistical Area.

History
The village was incorporated on April 16, 1878. The village was named after Alexander von Humboldt, a German natural scientist.

Geography
Humboldt is located at  (39.604140, -88.319676).

According to the 2010 census, Humboldt has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

At the 2000 census, there were 481 people, 183 households and 133 families residing in the town. The population density was . There were 199 housing units at an average density of . The racial make-up was 98.75% White, 0.21% Native American and 1.04% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 3.95% of the population.

There were 183 households, of which 35.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 62.8% were married couples living together, 8.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.8% were non-families. 23.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.63 and the average family size was 3.12.

27.4% of the population were under the age of 18, 8.5% from 18 to 24, 31.0% from 25 to 44, 21.0% from 45 to 64 and 12.1% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 33 years. For every 100 females, there were 90.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 88.6 males.

The median household income was $39,375 and the median family income was $45,625. Males had a median income of $29,688 and females $20,417. The per capita income was $16,244. About 1.6% of families and 6.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 5.3% of those under age 18 and 7.5% of those age 65 or over.

References

easy_general.text:
Humboldt is a small town in Coles County, Illinois. It has a population of 361 people and is part of the Charleston-Mattoon area.

History
Humboldt was founded on April 16, 1878. It was named after Alexander von Humboldt, a German scientist who studied nature.

Geography
Humboldt is located at 39.604140, -88.319676. It is a small town with a total area of , all land.

Demographics
In 2000, there were 481 people, 183 households, and 133 families living in Humboldt. The town was mostly white, with 98.75% of the population being white, 0.21% Native American, and 1.04% from other races. 3.95% of the population was Hispanic or Latino.

35% of the households had children under 18 living with them, and 63% were married couples living together. 8% were single mothers. 26.8% of households were single people, and 12% were people over 65 living alone. The average household size was 2.63, and the average family size was 3.12.

27.4% of the population were under the age of 18, 8.5% were between 18 and 24, 31% were between 25 and 44, 21% were between 45 and 64, and 12.1% were 65 or older. The median age was 33 years. For every 100 women, there were 90.9 men. For every 100 women aged 18 and over, there were 88.6 men.

The median household income was $39,375, and the median family income was $45,625. Males had a median income of $29,688, and females had a median income of $20,417. The per capita income was $16,244. About 1.6% of families and 6.7% of the population were below the poverty line.

adult_non_technical.text:
Humboldt is a small town in Coles County, Illinois. As of 2020, it had a population of 361 people. It's part of the Charleston-Mattoon area.

Humboldt was founded on April 16, 1878, and named after Alexander von Humboldt, a German natural scientist. The town is located at 39.604140 degrees north latitude and 88.319676 degrees west longitude.

According to 2000 census data, Humboldt had a population of 481 people, with 183 households, and 133 families. The population was about 98.75% white, 0.21% Native American, and 1.04% from other races. About 3.95% of the population was of Hispanic or Latino origin.

Of the 183 households, 35% had children under the age of 18, 62.8% were married couples living together, 8.7% were single mothers with children, and 26.8% were single-parent households. 23.5% of households were made up of individuals, and 12% had someone over 65 living alone. The average household size was 2.63, and the average family size was 3.12.

About 27% of the population was under 18 years of age, 8% between 18 and 24, 30% between 25 and 44, 21% between 45 and 64, and 12% over 65. The median age was 33 years. For every 100 women, there were 91 men. For every 100 women over 18, there were 89 men.

The median household income was $39,375, and the median family income was $45,625. Males had a median income of $29,688, and females $20,417. The per capita income was $16,244. About 1.6% of families and 6.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 5.3% of those under age 18.

samples.title: Boxtel
samples.original_text:
Boxtel () is a municipality and a town in the southern Netherlands. The name derives from Buchestelle and is presumably a combination of 'stelle' (Dutch for stable, safe place) and (deer) buck.

This is the origin of the Van Boxtel family, which has numerous descendants in North Brabant.

The town was the site of the Battle of Boxtel fought in September 1794 during the Flanders campaign. It is often principally remembered as the first battle of the future Duke of Wellington.

Population centres

Esch
Lennisheuvel
Liempde

Topography

Dutch topographic map of the municipality of Boxtel, 2021

Notable residents

easy_general.text:
Boxtel is a town and a place in the southern part of the Netherlands. The name comes from Buchestelle, which is probably a mix of "stelle" (meaning stable or safe place) and "buck" (a type of deer).

A family called the Van Boxtel family comes from this place, and they have many relatives in the area called North Brabant.

In 1794, a big fight happened in Boxtel called the Battle of Boxtel. This battle was led by someone who later became the Duke of Wellington.

adult_non_technical.text:
Boxtel is a town and a region in the southern Netherlands. The name comes from "Buchestelle," which probably means a safe place for deer. The Van Boxtel family comes from this area, and many of them live in North Brabant.

In 1794, a big battle took place in Boxtel as part of a larger war called the Flanders campaign. This battle is important because it was the first one for the future Duke of Wellington.

Boxtel has four main areas: Boxtel, Esch, Lennisheuvel, and Liempde. There are many famous people who live here, such as authors, designers, and athletes. The town also has a train station where people can catch trains.

adult_technical.text:
Boxtel is a municipality and town located in the southern Netherlands. The name "Bhestelle" is believed to be a combination of "stelle" (Dutch for stable or safe place) and "buck." This town is the origin of the Van Boxtel family, which has numerous descendants in North Brabant.

In 1794, the Battle of Boxtel took place in the town during the Flanders campaign. This battle is often remembered as the first battle of the future Duke of Wellington.

Population centers in Boxtel include Boxtel, Esch, Lennisheuvel, and Liempde.

Topography of Boxtel can be found in the Dutch topographic map from 2021.

Notable residents of Boxtel include José van Dijck, a new media author and academic; Teun Voeten, a Dutch photojournalist and cultural anthropologist; Marcel Wanders, a Dutch designer and art director; Dianne van Giersbergen, a spinto soprano and singer-songwriter; and Sam Feldt, a Dutch DJ and record producer.

Boxtel has produced several notable sports figures, including Jeroen Delmee, a field hockey player and twice Olympic champion; Bas van Erp, a wheelchair Paralympic tennis player; Frank van der Struijk, a Dutch footballer with over 300 club caps; Michael van Gerwen, a Dutch professional and 3-time World Darts Champion; Glenn Schuurman, a Dutch field hockey player who competed at the 2016 Summer Olympics; and Silvinho Esajas, a Dutch professional footballer.

Boxtel is served by a railway station.

samples.title: Parry Peninsula
samples.original_text:
The Parry Peninsula on the north coast of Canada's Northwest Territories is bounded on the west by Franklin Bay, on the north by Amundsen Gulf, and on the east by Darnley Bay.The nearest settlement is Paulatuk. It is also home to the Cape Parry Migratory Bird Sanctuary on the northern extremity of the Parry Peninsula.

History
It is named for the Arctic explorer William Edward Parry. On the northern tip of the peninsula is Cape Parry. A headland, and a Distant Early Warning Line site on Parry Peninsula northern tip.

See also
Cape Parry
Paulatuk
Distant Early Warning Line

References

Further reading

Peninsulas of the Northwest Territories

easy_general.text:
The Parry Peninsula is a piece of land in the northern part of Canada, in the Northwest Territories. It is surrounded by Franklin Bay on the west, Amundsen Gulf on the north, and Darnley Bay on the east. The closest town is Paulatuk. There is also a special place called the Cape Parry Migratory Bird Sanctuary at the very top of the peninsula.

History
The Parry Peninsula is named after a famous Arctic explorer named William Edward Parry. At the very top of the peninsula, there is a place called Cape Parry, which is a big point of land. There is also a special place called the Distant Early Warning Line site at the very top of the peninsula.

See also
Cape Parry
Paulatuk
Distant Early Warning Line

References

Further reading

Peninsulas of the Northwest Territories

adult_non_technical.text:
The Parry Peninsula is a long piece of land on the north coast of Canada's Northwest Territories. It's surrounded by Franklin Bay on the west, Amundsen Gulf on the north, and Darnley Bay on the east. The closest town is Paulatuk, and there's also a special place called the Cape Parry Migratory Bird Sanctuary at the northern end of the peninsula.

The name Parry Peninsula comes from a famous Arctic explorer named William Edward Parry. At the very top of the peninsula is Cape Parry, a big piece of land that sticks out into the water. There's also a place called the Distant Early Warning Line site on the northern tip of the peninsula, which helps people watch for changes in the area.

For more information, check out the Peninsulas of the Northwest Territories.

adult_technical.text:
The Parry Peninsula, situated on the northern coast of Canada's Northwest Territories, is bounded on the west by Franklin Bay, on the north by Amundsen Gulf, and on the east by Darnley Bay. The nearest settlement is Paulatuk, and the Cape Parry Migratory Bird Sanctuary is located at the northern extremity of the peninsula.

History
The Parry Peninsula is named after the renowned Arctic explorer William Edward Parry. At the northern tip of the peninsula lies Cape Parry, a headland that served as a site for the Distant Early Warning Line, a Cold War-era radar system designed to detect incoming Soviet missile attacks.

See Also
1. Cape Parry
2. Paulatuk
3. Distant Early Warning Line

The 1460s BC was a decade lasting from January 1, 1469 BC to December 31, 1460 BC.

Events and trends
 c. 1469 BC—In the Battle of Megiddo, Egypt defeats Canaan.

Significant people
 Hatshepsut of Egypt, female Pharaoh of the 18th Dynasty (1473 BC–1458 BC)

easy_general.text: The 1460s BC was a period of 10 years from January 1, 1469 BC to December 31, 1460 BC. During this time, some important events happened, like the Battle of Megiddo, where Egypt defeated Canaan. There was also a female leader named Hatshepsut in Egypt, who ruled during the 18th Dynasty from 1473 BC to 1458 BC.

adult_non_technical.text: The 1460s BC was a decade that lasted from January 1, 1469 BC to December 31,1460 BC. During this time, an important event happened called the Battle of Megiddo. It was between Egypt and Canaan, and Egypt won. There was also a powerful female leader named Hatshepsut who ruled Egypt during this time. She was part of the 18th Dynasty and ruled from 1473 BC to 1458 BC.

adult_technical.text:
The 1460s BC, spanning from January 1, 1469 BC, to December 31, 1460 BC, was a decade marked by significant events and notable figures. Among the key events of this period was the approximate 1469 BC Battle of Megiddo, which resulted in Egypt's victory over Canaan. This conflict marked a pivotal moment in the history of the Near East, as it solidified Egypt's position as a dominant power in the region.

During this time, Hatshepsut, the female Pharaoh of the 18th Dynasty (1473 BC–1458 BC), played a crucial role in shaping the course of Egyptian history. Hatshepsut's reign was characterized by a period of peace and prosperity, as she oversaw the expansion of trade and the construction of grand monuments, including the famous Temple of Hatshepsut at Luxor.

samples.title: Abatement of debts and legacies
samples.original_text:
Abatement of debts and legacies is a common law doctrine of wills that holds that when the equitable assets of a deceased person are not sufficient to satisfy fully all the creditors, their debts must abate proportionately, and they must accept a dividend.

In the case of legacies when the funds or assets out of which they are payable are not sufficient to pay them in full, the legacies abate in proportion, unless there is a priority given specially to any particular legacy. Annuities are also subject to the same rule as general legacies.

The order of abatement is usually:
 Intestate property
 The residuary of the estate
 General Devises—i.e., cash gifts
 Demonstrative Devises—i.e., cash gifts from a specific account, stocks, bonds, securities, etc.
 Specific Devises—i.e., specified items of personal property, real property, etc.
Non-probate property—i.e., life insurance policies—do not abate.

Definitions
A specific devise, is a specific gift in a will to a specific person other than an amount of money. For example, if James's will states that he is leaving his $500,000 yacht to his brother Mike, the yacht would be a specific devise.

A general devise, is a monetary gift to a specific person to be satisfied out of the overall estate. For example, if James's will states that he is leaving $500,000 to his son Sam then the money would be a general devise.

A demonstrative devise, is money given from a particular account.  For example, "$10,000 to be paid from the sale of my GM stock."

A residual devise is one left to a devisee after all specific and general devices have been made.  For example, James's will might say: "I give all the rest, residue and remainder of my estate to my daughter Lilly." Lilly would be the residual devisee and entitled to James's residuary estate.

References

Common law
Wills and trusts

easy_general.text:
When someone dies and doesn't have enough money to pay all their debts, there's a rule called "abatement of debts and legacies." This means that the debts and gifts in their will must be reduced in proportion to how much money they have.

Here's the order in which things are reduced:

1. Intestate property: Property without a will.
2. Residuary estate: Property left in a will.
3. General devises: Cash gifts from the estate.
4. Demonstrative devises: Cash gifts from a specific account, like stocks or bonds.
5. Specific devises: Specific items of property left to a specific person, like a car or a house.

For example, if James leaves his $500,000 yacht to his brother Mike, that's a specific devise. If, instead, he leaves $500,000 to his son Sam, that's a general devise. If he leaves $10,000 to be paid from the sale of his GM stock, that's a demonstrative devise.

adult_non_technical.text:
When someone dies and doesn't have enough money to pay off all their debts, there's a rule called "abatement of debts and legacies" that helps decide who gets what. This rule is part of the common law, which is a set of laws that have been around for a long time.

The rule says that if the person's assets aren't enough to cover all their debts, the debts must be reduced in proportion. This means that creditors will get a smaller amount of what they're owed. If there are legacies, which are gifts in a will, and there's not enough money to pay them, the legacies will be reduced as well. This also applies to annuities, which are regular payments from the estate.

The order in which legacies are reduced is usually as follows:
- Intate property, which is property that isn't mentioned in the will
- The residuary of the estate, which is the remaining property after all specific legacies have been given
- General legacies, which are cash gifts
- Demonstrative legacies, which are cash gifts from a specific account
- Specific legacies, which are specific items mentioned in the will, like a car or a house

Non probate property, like life insurance policies, doesn't get reduced.

Here are some definitions:
- Specific devise: A specific gift in a will to a specific person, other than a cash amount. For example, if James leaves his yacht to his brother Mike, the yacht is a specific devise.
- General devise: A cash gift to a specific person. For example, if James leaves $500,000 to his son Sam, the money is a general devise.
- Demonstrative devise: A cash gift from a specific account. For example, if James leaves $10,000 to be paid from the sale of his GM stock, that's a demonstrative devise.
- Residual devise: A gift that's left to a person after all specific and general legacies have been given. For example, if James's will says, "I give all the rest, residue and remainder of my estate to my daughter Lilly," Lilly is the residual devisee and gets the residuary estate.

References:
- Common law
- Wills and trusts

samples.title: Gilding metal
samples.original_text:
Gilding metal is a form of brass (an alloy of copper and zinc) with a much higher copper content than zinc content. Exact figures range from 95% copper and 5% zinc to “8 parts copper to 1 of zinc” (11% zinc) in British Army Dress Regulations.

Gilding metal is used for various purposes, including the jackets of bullets, driving bands on some artillery shells, as well as enameled badges and other jewellery. The sheet is widely used for craft metalworking by hammer working. It is also used particularly as a lower-cost training material for silversmiths.  Starting in 1944, shell casings made of gilding metal were melted down by the United States Mint to be made into pennies.  These pennies replaced the less popular steel cent of 1943, and the pennies of this composition were produced until 1946.

Gilding metal was also used for the "bronze" Olympic medal at the 2020 Summer Olympics held in Tokyo, Japan in 2021.

Gilding metal may be annealed by heating to between . It should be cooled slowly afterwards, to reduce risk of cracking.

References 

Copper alloys
Brass
Ammunition

easy_general.text:
Gilding metal is a type of brass, which is a mix of copper and zinc. It has a lot more copper than zinc. People use it for different things, like bullet jackets, metal bands on some shells, and some jewelry. It's also used for making metal things by hammering, and for silversmiths to practice with.

In 1944, the United States Mint melted down shell casings made of gilding metal to make pennies. These pennies were used until 1946.

adult_non_technical.text:

This metal is used for different things, like bullet jackets, metal bands on artillery shells, and some jewelry. It's also used for making things by hammering, and as a training material for silversmiths. Gilding metal was even used to make the bronze medal at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo.

To make gilding metal easier to work with, people heat it up to a certain temperature and let it cool slowly. This is called annealing.

adult_technical.text:
Gilding metal is a type of brass, an alloy composed of copper and zinc, characterized by a significantly higher copper content compared to zinc. The exact composition can range from 95% copper and 5% zinc to 8 parts copper to 1 part zinc, or 11% zinc, as specified in the British Army Dress Regulations.

Gilding metal finds use in various applications, including the production of bullet jackets, driving bands on certain artillery shells, and enameled badges and jewelry. Its sheet form is commonly employed in craft metalworking, particularly for hammer working. Additionally, gilding metal serves as an affordable training material for silversmiths.

In 1944, the United States Mint began recycling shell casings made of gilding metal to produce pennies. These pennies replaced the less popular steel cent of 1943 and were manufactured until 1946. Furthermore, in 2021 gilding metal was utilized for the "bronze" Olympic medal at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan.

To enhance its properties and performance, gilding metal can be subjected to an annealing process. This involves heating the metal to a temperature range between , followed by a slow cooling process to minimize the risk of cracking.

References:
Copper alloys
Brass
Ammunition

samples.title: AD 145
samples.original_text:
Year 145 (CXLV) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Hadrianus and Caesar (or, less frequently, year 898 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 145 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events

By place

Roman Empire 
 Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar become Roman Consuls.
 Marcus Aurelius marries Faustina the Younger, the daughter of Antoninus Pius.
 Arrian becomes archon in Athens.

Asia 
 Change of emperor from Han Chongdi to Han Zhidi of the Chinese Han Dynasty.

Births 
 April 11 – Septimius Severus, Roman emperor (d. 211)

Deaths 
 Han Chongdi, Chinese emperor of the Han Dynasty (b. 143)

References

easy_general.text: In the year 145, which was a common year in the Julian calendar, some important things happened. At that time, people called this year the Year of the Consulship of Hadrianus and Caesar, or sometimes 898 Ab urbe condita. In the Roman Empire, two men named Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar became important leaders called consuls. Marcus Aurelius also married Faustina the Younger, the daughter of Antoninus Pius. In Asia, the emperor of the Chinese Han Dynasty changed from Han Chongdi to Han Zhidi. During this year, a new Roman emperor named Septimius Severus was born, and the Chinese emperor Han Chongdi passed away.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 145, which was a common year in the Julian calendar, several significant events occurred. At the time, this year was known as the Year of the Consulship of Hadrianus and Caesar, or less commonly as year 898 Ab urbe condita. The number 145 has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became popular in Europe.

Notable events in the Roman Empire include:
- Roman Consuls Antoninus Augustus Pius and Marcus Aurelius Caesar took office.
- Marcus Aurelius married Faustina the Younger, the daughter of Antoninus Pius.
- Arrian became the archon in Athens.

In Asia, the Chinese Han Dynasty experienced a change of emperor from Han Chongdi to Han Zhidi.

On April 11, Septimius Severus, a future Roman emperor, was born and died 211 years later. In 143, Han Chongdi, the Chinese emperor of the Han Dynasty, passed away.

References

adult_technical.text:
The year 145, denoted as CXLV in the Julian calendar, was a common year commencing on a Thursday (link will display the full calendar). During this period, it was referred to as the Year of the Consulship of Hadrianus and Caesar, or less commonly as year 898 Ab urbe condita. The designation of 145 for this year has been in use since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the dominant method in Europe for year naming.

samples.title: Termination type
samples.original_text:
In lithic reduction, termination type is a characteristic indicating the manner in which the distal end of a lithic flake detaches from a core (Andrefsky 1998:18).  Common types include:

 Step/snap termination – these occur when a flake snaps or breaks during removal, resulting in an abrupt right-angle break.
 Hinge termination – results when the applied force rolls away from the core or objective piece, creating a rounded or blunted distal end.
 Overshot/outrepasse/plunging termination - occurs when the applied force dips and removes a section of the opposite margin of the artifact or the distal end of the core.  Also referred to as a reverse hinge termination.
 Perverse termination - "twisting" breaks resulting from when the applied force is redirected through the material in a helical fashion;
 Feather/monotomic termination – a smooth termination that results in a feathered distal end.  The distal ends of these flakes are only a few molecules thick, are extremely sharp, and indicate a flawless detachment.  These are the intended results of some lithic reduction techniques, and are very desirable for opportunistic tool use that does not require retouching or sharpening.

References
 Andrefsky, William, Jr. (1998) Lithics: Macroscopic approaches to analysis.  Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

Lithics

easy_general.text:
When people make stone tools, they use a process called "lithic reduction." This involves breaking off small pieces from a larger core to create a tool. The way these small pieces break off from the core is called the "termination type." There are different types of terminations:

1. Step/snap termination: This happens when the small piece snaps or breaks off, creating a sharp right-angle break. It's like when you tear a piece of paper and it breaks along a clean line.

2. Hinge termination: This occurs when the force used to remove the small piece rolls away from the core, creating a rounded or blunted end. Think of it like when you bend a piece of paper and it forms a smooth curve.

3. Overshot/outrepasse/plunging termination: This happens when the force dips and removes a section of the opposite margin of the artifact or the distal end of the core. It's like when you fold a piece of paper and it creates a crease on the opposite side.

4. Perverse termination: This is like a "twisting" break that occurs when the force is redirected through the material in a helical fashion. It's like when you twist a piece of paper and it forms a spiral.

5. Feather/monotomic termination: This is a smooth termination that results in a feathered distal end. The distal ends of these flakes are only a few molecules thick, are extremely sharp, and indicate a flawless detachment. It's like when you cut a piece of paper with a sharp knife and it creates a clean, smooth edge.

These terminations are important because they tell us about the way people made the stone tools and the techniques they used. They also help us understand how the tools were used and how they evolved over time.

adult_non_technical.text:
When people make stone tools, they use a process called "lithic reduction." This involves breaking off small pieces from a larger stone to create a tool. There are several ways to describe the manner in which the small pieces leave the larger stone. These ways are called "flake termination types."

Some common flake types include:

1. Step/snap termination: This happens when a flake breaks or snaps during removal, resulting in a sharp right-angle break.
2. Hinge termination: When the force applied to the flake rolls away from the core or objective piece, it creates a rounded or blunted distal end.
3. Overshot/outrepasse/plunging termination: This occurs when the applied force dips and removes a section of the opposite margin of the artifact or the distal end of the core. This is also called a reverse hinge termination.
4. Perverse termination: These are "twisting" breaks resulting when the applied force is redirected through the material in a helical fashion.
5. Feather/monotomic termination: This is a smooth termination that results in a feathered distal end. The distal ends of these flakes are only a few molecules thick, are extremely sharp, and indicate a flawless detachment. These are the intended results of some lithic reduction techniques and are very desirable for opportunistic tool use that does not require retouching or sharpening.

References:
Andrefsky, William, Jr. (1998) Lithics: Macroscopic approaches to analysis. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

adult_technical.text:
In the context of lithic reduction, termination type refers to the manner in which the distal end of a lithic flake detaches from a core (Andrefsky 1998:18). Some common types of termination include:

Step/snap termination: This occurs when a flake snaps or breaks during removal, resulting in an abrupt right-angle break.

Hinge termination: This results when the applied force rolls away from the core or objective piece, creating a rounded or blunted distal end.

Overshot/outrepasse/plunging termination: This occurs when the applied force dips and removes a section of the opposite margin of the artifact or the distal end of the core. This type of termination is also referred to as a reverse hinge termination.

Perverse termination: This is a "twisting" break resulting from when the applied force is redirected through the material in a helical fashion.

Feather/monotomic termination: This is a smooth termination that results in a feathered distal end. The distal ends of these flakes are only a few molecules thick, are extremely sharp, and indicate a flawless detachment. These are the intended results of some lithic reduction techniques, and are very desirable for opportunistic tool use that does not require retouching or sharpening.

References:
Andrefsky, William, Jr. (1998) Lithics: Macroscopic approaches to analysis. Cambridge University Press, Cambridge.

samples.title: IPY
samples.original_text:
IPY or Ipy may refer to:

 International Polar Year, year of international research focused on the polar regions
 Ipy (goddess), an ancient Egyptian mother goddess depicted as a hippopotamus
 Ipy (noble), a court official who was part of the 18th Dynasty of Ancient Egypt

easy_general.text:
IPY or Ipy can mean different things:

1. International Polar Year: This is a year when scientists from all over the world come together to study the North and South poles.
2. Ipy (goddess): This is an ancient Egyptian mother goddess who looks like a hippopotamus.
3. Ipy (noble): This was a high-ranking official in the 18th Dynasty of Egypt.

adult_non_technical.text:
IPY or Ipy can refer to different things:

- International Polar Year, a time when scientists from many countries come together to study the cold regions like Antarctica and the Arctic
- Ipy, an ancient Egyptian goddess who was shown as a hippopotamus
- Ipy, a high-ranking official from the 18th Dynasty of Ancient Egypt

adult_technical.text:
The term IPY or Ipy can refer to three distinct entities:

1. The International Polar Year (IPY), a year of international scientific research focused on the polar regions.
2. The mother goddess Ipy in ancient Egyptian mythology, depicted as a hippopotamus.
3. A court official named Ipy who was part of the 18th Dynasty of Ancient Egypt.

easy_general.text:
A "session" can mean different things depending on the context. Here are some examples:

In government and law:
- A session in parliamentary procedure is like a meeting where people make decisions and discuss laws.
- A session in Presbyterian polity is a group of people who help run a Presbyterian church.
- The Court of Session in Scotland is the highest court for civil cases.
- An executive session in the U.S. Senate is a part of their meeting where they discuss things in private.
- A legislative session is a period of time when lawmakers work on laws.

In computing:
- A session in computer science is like a conversation between two devices.
- In web analytics, a session measures how long someone stays on a website.
- A session in operating systems is a group of tasks that work together.
- CD sessions are how information is organized on a CD or DVD.
- A login session is when you log in to a computer.
- Session (software) is a way to send messages securely.

In music:
- A jam session is when musicians get together to play music.
- A pub session is playing music in a bar.
- A recording session is when musicians record music together.

In music works:
- "Session" is an instrumental song by Linkin Park from their 2003 album Meteora.
- "Session" is a song by The Offspring from their 1992 album Ignition.
- "Session" is a song by Tyler the Creator from the album Bastard.

Other uses in music:
- CD sessions are how data is organized on a CD or DVD.
- Session musicians are musicians who are available for hire.

Other uses:
- An academic term is sometimes called a "session."
- The Session of Christ is a Christian belief about Jesus' place in heaven.
- Session (video game) is a skateboarding game planned for 2019.
- Session is a 2018 short film directed by Buğra Mert Alkayalar.

samples.title: Mass media in Laos
samples.original_text:
Mass media in Laos are based on a network of telephone lines and radiotelephone communications in remote areas, as well as mobile phone infrastructure. The system is not well-developed.

Infrastructure and statistics
In 1997 there were 25,000 telephone lines in use, and in 2007 there were 850,000 mobile cellular subscribers. Laos is served by a Russian Intersputnik satellite that covers the Indian Ocean region.

In 1998 there were 12 AM stations and one FM station. In 1997 there were an estimated 730,000 radios in the country. In 2011 Laos had three television channels. In 2000 there was one Internet service provider, by 2002 serving about 10,000 users. The top-level domain for Laos is .la.

See also
 Telephone numbers in Laos
 Internet in Laos

References 

 
Laos
Laos

easy_general.text: In Laos, communication is done through phone lines, mobile phones, and radiotelephone communications in remote areas. The system is not very advanced, but it's getting better. In 1997, there were 25,000 phone lines, and by 2007, there were 850,000 mobile phone users. Laos also has a satellite that covers the Indian Ocean region. The country has several radio stations, three TV channels, and one internet service provider. The top-level domain for Laos is .la.

adult_non_technical.text: In Laos, people communicate using a mix of phone lines, mobile phones, and radio. The system isn't very advanced, but it's getting better. There are also some TV channels and internet access.

adult_technical.text:
The telecommunications infrastructure in Laos is primarily based on a network of telephone lines and radiotelephone communications, with the addition of mobile phone infrastructure in recent years. However, the system remains underdeveloped compared to other countries in the region.

Infrastructure and statistics
In 1997, there were 25,000 telephone lines in use, and by 2007, the number of mobile cellular subscribers had grown to 850,000. Laos is served by a Russian Intersputnik satellite that covers the Indian Ocean region.

In 1998, there were 12 AM stations and one FM station. In 1997, there were an estimated 730,000 radios in the country. In 2011, Laos had three television channels. In 2000, there was one Internet service provider, which by 2002 was serving about 10,000 users. The top-level domain for Laos is .la.

samples.title: Center Creek Township, Martin County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Center Creek Township is a township in Martin County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 269 at the 2000 census.

This township took its name from Center Creek.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which   is land and   (0.08%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 269 people, 106 households, and 78 families residing in the township.  The population density was 7.6 people per square mile (2.9/km2).  There were 111 housing units at an average density of 3.1/sq mi (1.2/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.51% White, and 1.49% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.86% of the population.

There were 106 households, out of which 26.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 64.2% were married couples living together, 3.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.4% were non-families. 20.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.54 and the average family size was 2.88.

In the township the population was spread out, with 23.0% under the age of 18, 8.6% from 18 to 24, 25.3% from 25 to 44, 27.1% from 45 to 64, and 16.0% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females, there were 100.7 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 105.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $40,859, and the median income for a family was $41,477. Males had a median income of $26,389 versus $18,750 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,689.  About 2.6% of families and 3.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including none of those under the age of eighteen and 5.6% of those 65 or over.

References

Townships in Martin County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

easy_general.text:
Center Creek Township is a place in Martin County, Minnesota. It had 269 people living there in 2000. The township is named after a stream called Center Creek.

Center Creek Township covers a total area of about 100 square miles. Most of it is land, with a tiny bit of water (only 0.08% of the total area).

In 2000, there were 269 people, 106 families, and 111 houses in Center Creek Township. The population density was 7.6 people per square mile. The majority of the people were white (98.51%), and the remaining 1.49% were from different races. About 1.86% of the population was of Hispanic or Latino descent.

Of the 106 families, 26.4% had children under the age of 18, 64.2% were married couples living together, and 26.4% were single families. The average household size was 2.54 people, and the average family size was 2.88 people.

The population was spread out, with 23% of people under 18, 8.6% between 18 and 24, a group of 25 to 44, 27.1% between 45 and 64, and the remaining 16% were 65 or older. The median age was 42 years. For every 100 women, there were 100.7 men, and for every 100 women aged 18 and over, there were 105 men.

The average household income was $40,859, and the average family income was $41,477. Men earned an average of $26,389, while women earned an average of $18,750. The per capita income was $16,689. About 2.6% of families and 3.6% of the population lived below the poverty line, with no one under 18 and 5.6% of those 65 or older.

For more information, check out Townships in Martin County, Minnesota and Townships in Minnesota.

samples.title: Helsingborg Municipality
samples.original_text:
Helsingborg Municipality (Helsingborgs kommun) is a municipality in Scania County in Sweden. Its seat is located in the city of Helsingborg, which is Sweden's eighth largest city. The municipality had a population of 
147,734 on January 1, 2019, and the metro has about 320,000 inhabitants.

Between 1912 and 1971 the name of the town was officially spelled Hälsingborg (rather like the region of Hälsingland but unlike neighbouring Danish Helsingør and the Finnish capital Helsingfors (Helsinki)). The spelling was changed back to the older version when the present municipality was created in 1971 through the amalgamation of the Town of Hälsingborg with four surrounding rural municipalities. Since the 1990s the municipality again styles itself Helsingborgs stad (Town of Helsingborg). This usage is only nominal and has no effect on the status of the municipality.

Localities

As of 2018, there were 16 urban areas the municipality.

International relations

Twin towns — sister cities
Helsingborg is twinned with:
 Alexandria, United States
 Dubrovnik, Croatia

 Liepāja, Latvia
 Pärnu, Estonia

See also
 Municipalities of Sweden
 European route E4

References
Statistics Sweden

External links

Helsingborg Municipality - Official site
The local daily newspaper

 
Municipalities of Skåne County
Scania

From 1912 to 1971, the town's name was spelled Hälsingborg, like the region of Hälsingland, but not like the Danish city Helsingør or the Finnish capital Helsinki. In 1971, the spelling changed back to Helsingborg when the municipality was formed by combining the town with four rural areas. Since the 1990s, the municipality has called itself "Helsingborgs stad" or "Town of Helsingborg," but this is just a name and doesn't change its status.

There are 16 urban areas in the municipality as of 2018.

Helsingborg has relationships with other cities around the world, like Alexandria in the United States, Dubrovnik in Croatia, Liepāja in Latvia, and Pärnu in Estonia. These relationships are called "twin towns" or "sister cities."

For more information, you can check out the official website of Helsingborg Municipality or the local newspaper.

easy_general.text:
ICD stands for International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems. It's a tool used by doctors and researchers around the world to identify and understand different diseases and health issues.

ICD can also refer to different organizations, technologies, and other things:

Organizations:
- The Information Control Division of the US Army in Germany after World War II
- The United States Army Medical Research Institute of Chemical Defense (USAMRICD or ICD)
- The Iranian Club in Dubai
- The Islamic Corporation for the Development of the Private Sector, part of the Islamic Development Bank
- International Clothing Designs, a UK company that imports clothing

Science and Technology:
- In-circuit debugger, a tool used in electronic hardware development
- Interface control document, used in systems and software engineering
- MPLAB devices ICD, a type of in-circuit debugger
- Interatomic Coulombic decay, a relaxation process in physics

Medicine:
- Immunogenic cell death, a type of cell death that triggers an immune response
- Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator, a device that helps regulate heart rhythms
- Impulse control disorder, a condition where people have trouble controlling their impulses
- Isobaric counterdiffusion, a process in cell biology

Other Uses:
- Doctor of Canon Law, a degree in church law
- Incentive-centered design, a way of designing products that encourages people to use them
- Inland container depot of Container Corporation of India, a place where containers are stored

See also: Intelligence Community Directive 301 (ICD-301)

adult_non_technical.text: ICD is a tool that helps doctors around the world understand and treat diseases.

adult_technical.text: The International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (ICD) serves as a standard diagnostic tool for global health. However, the term "ICD" can also refer to various other entities and concepts.

samples.title: Pope Pelagius II
samples.original_text:
Pope Pelagius II (died 7 February 590) was the bishop of Rome from 26 November 579 to his death.

Life
Pelagius was a native of Rome, but probably of Ostrogothic descent, as his father's name was Winigild. Pelagius became Pope Benedict I's successor on November 26, 579, without imperial confirmation.

Pelagius appealed for help from Emperor Maurice against the Lombards, but to no avail, forcing Pelagius to "buy" a truce and turn to the Franks, who invaded Italy, but left after being bribed by the Lombards.

Pelagius labored to promote clerical celibacy, and he issued stringent regulations on this matter. During his pontificate, the bishop of Milan, who had broken communion with Rome in the Schism of the Three Chapters, returned to full communion around 581, while other bishops in Northern Italy remained in schism.

Pelagius ordered the construction of the Basilica di San Lorenzo fuori le Mura, a church shrine over the place where Saint Lawrence was martyred. During his reign, the Visigoths of Spain converted, but he also faced conflict with the See of Constantinople over the adoption of the title of "Ecumenical Patriarch," which Pelagius believed to undermine the authority of the papacy.

Pelagius fell victim to the plague that devastated Rome at the end of 590. His successor, Gregory I, thought his regulations of clerical celibacy too strict, and modified them to some extent.

References

590 deaths
Popes
Italian popes
6th-century deaths from plague (disease)
Popes of the Byzantine Papacy
6th-century archbishops
Year of birth unknown
520 births
6th-century popes

easy_general.text:
Pope Pelagius II was the leader of the Catholic Church from 26 November 579 until his death on 7 February 590. He was born in Rome but may have come from a family of Ostrogothic descent since his father was Winigild. He became Pope after Benedict I, without the approval of the emperor.

Pelagius tried to get help from Emperor Maurice against the Lombards, but it didn't work. So, he had to buy a truce and ask the Franks for help. The Franks invaded Italy but left after being bribed by the Lombards.

Pelagius worked to make sure that priests didn't get married. He made strict rules about this. During his time, the bishop of Milan, who had broken ties with Rome, returned to full communion around 581. However, other bishops in Northern Italy remained divided.

Pelagius ordered the building of the Basilica di San Lorenzo fuori le Mura, a church where Saint Lawrence was killed. During his reign, the Visigoths of Spain converted to Christianity. But he also had disagreements with the See of Constantinople over the title of "Ecumenical Patriarch," which he thought weakened the power of the Pope.

Pelagius died from a plague that hit Rome at the end of 590. His successor, Gregory I, thought Pelagius's rules about priests not getting married were too strict and changed them a bit.

Pelagius tried to get help from Emperor Maurice against the Lombards, but it didn't work. So, he had to buy a truce and ask the Franks for help. The Franks invaded Italy but left after being bribed by the Lombards.

Pelagius worked hard to encourage priests to stay single, and he made strict rules about it. During his time, the bishop of Milan, who had broken ties with Rome, returned to full communion around 581. However, other bishops in Northern Italy remained in schism.

Pelagius was dedicated to promoting clerical celibacy and issued stringent regulations on this matter. During his pontificate, the bishop of Milan, who had broken communion with Rome in the Schism of the Three Chapters, returned to full communion around 581. However, other bishops in Northern Italy remained in schism.

Pelagius commissioned the construction of the Basilica di San Lorenzo fuori le Mura, a church shrine over the site where Saint Lawrence was martyred. During his reign, the Visigoths of Spain converted to Christianity, but he faced conflict with the See of Constantinople over the adoption of the title of "Ecumenical Patriarch," which Pelagius believed to undermine the authority of the papacy.

Pelagius succumbed to the plague that devastated Rome at the end of 590. His successor, Gregory I, found Pelagius's regulations on clerical celibacy too stringent and modified them to some extent.

samples.title: Burdell Township, Michigan
samples.original_text:
Burdell Township is a civil township of Osceola County in the U.S. state of Michigan.  As of the 2000 census, the township population was 1,241.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  is land and  (0.56%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 1,241 people, 478 households, and 351 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.2 per square mile (12.8/km2).  There were 713 housing units at an average density of 19.1 per square mile (7.4/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.55% White, 0.08% African American, 0.32% Native American, 0.24% Asian, and 0.81% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.48% of the population.

There were 478 households, out of which 31.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 61.3% were married couples living together, 8.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.4% were non-families. 20.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.59 and the average family size was 3.00.

In the township the population was spread out, with 26.0% under the age of 18, 6.9% from 18 to 24, 28.0% from 25 to 44, 26.0% from 45 to 64, and 13.1% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 101.1 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.8 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $35,481, and the median income for a family was $40,815. Males had a median income of $30,521 versus $20,294 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,375.  About 8.8% of families and 13.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 15.5% of those under age 18 and 9.1% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Michigan

samples.title: Salhouse Broad
samples.original_text:
Salhouse Broad, one of the Norfolk Broads, is situated on the River Bure in The Broads in Norfolk, England.

The broad is situated just off the river and attracts little through traffic. It lies south of Hoveton Great Broad and approximately half a mile north of the village of Salhouse. Salhouse Broad is accessible from the landward side and moorings are also permitted to fee-paying boat visitors. It is privately owned and managed in conjunction with the community of Salhouse. The broad covers an area of  and is home to many forms of wildlife including the Norfolk hawker dragonfly and the swallowtail butterfly. Black swans have been recorded on this broad. Salhouse Broad is unusual in being the result of the flooding of tenth century sand and gravel diggings, not of peat diggings like most of the broads.

References

Norfolk Broads

easy_general.text:
Salhouse Broad is a beautiful part of the Norfolk Broads, located on the River Bure in Norfolk, England. It's just off the river, so it's not very busy with traffic. It's south of Hoveton Great Broad and about half a mile north of the village of Salhouse. You can visit Salhouse Broad from the land, and if you have a boat, you can park it there. The area is owned by the local community.

Salhouse Broad is home to many types of animals, like the Norfolk hawker dragonfly and the swallowtail butterfly. You might even see a black swan there. What makes this broad special is that it was formed when sand and gravel pits flooded, unlike most of the other broads that were created by peat digging.

adult_non_technical.text: Salhouse Broad is a beautiful area on the River Bure in Norfolk, England. It's part of the Norfolk Broads, which are a series of natural lakes and wetlands. This area is just off the river, so it doesn't get a lot of traffic. It's south of Hoveton Great Broad and about half a mile north of the village of Salhouse. You can visit it by land or by boat, but you need to pay a fee to use the moorings. The area is owned and managed by the community of Salhouse. It's home to many types of wildlife, including the Norfolk hawker dragonfly and the swallowtail butterfly. Black swans have also been seen here. This area is unique because it was formed when old sand and gravel pits flooded.

samples.title: Amoz
samples.original_text:
Amoz  (), also known as Amotz, was the father of the prophet Isaiah, mentioned in Isaiah 1:1; 2:1 and 13:1, and in II Kings 19:2, 20; 20:1. Nothing else is known for certain about him.

There is a Talmudic tradition that when the name of a prophet's father is given, the father was also a prophet, so that Amoz would have been a prophet like his son. Though it is mentioned frequently as the patronymic title of Isaiah, the name Amoz appears nowhere else in the Bible. The rabbis of the Talmud declared, based upon a rabbinic tradition, that Amoz was the brother of Amaziah (אמציה), the king of Judah at that time (and, as a result, that Isaiah himself was a member of the royal family). According to some traditions, Amoz is the "man of God" in 2 Chronicles 25:7–9 (Seder Olam Rabbah 20), who cautioned Amaziah to release the Israelite mercenaries that he had hired.

References

Prophets in Judaism
Hebrew Bible people
Isaiah

easy_general.text: Amoz, also known as Amotz, was the father of the famous prophet Isaiah. We know very little about Amoz, but he is mentioned in some parts of the Bible. According to an old tradition, Amoz was also a prophet, just like his son Isaiah. The name Amoz is rarely mentioned in the Bible, but it is believed that he was the brother of the king of Judah, Amaziah. Some people think that Amoz was the one who warned Amaziah to release the Israelite soldiers he had hired.

adult_non_technical.text:
Amoz, also known as Amotz, was the father of the famous prophet Isaiah. His name appears in the Bible in Isaiah 1:1, 2:1, and 13:1, and in II Kings 19:2 and 20:1. Not much is known about Amoz, but there is a tradition in the Talmud that when the name of a prophet's father is mentioned, the father was also a prophet. This means that Amoz would have been a prophet as well.

The name Amoz is mentioned frequently in the Bible, but only as a "patronymic title" for Isaiah, which means it's used to describe his father. The rabbis of the Talmud believed that Amoz was the brother of Amaziah, the king of Judah at that time. This would mean that Isaiah himself was part of the royal family.

In some traditions, Amoz is also seen as the "man of God" in 2 Chronicles 25:7-9, who advised Amaziah to release the Israelite mercenaries he had hired.

samples.title: Lycoris (company)
samples.original_text:
Lycoris, (formerly Redmond Linux Corp.), was started in the year 2000 with the intent to make free software easy enough for anyone to use. Redmond Linux was founded by Joseph Cheek, an entrepreneur who had previously worked for Linuxcare. In late 2001 it merged with embedded systems company DeepLinux; the merged entity was named Redmond Linux Corporation. The company's first product was Redmond Linux Personal, an easy-to-use Linux desktop operating system. The company was renamed Lycoris in January 2002 and its assets were acquired by Mandriva on June 15, 2005.

The flagship product of Lycoris was Lycoris Desktop/LX, a Linux distribution.
The company was based in Maple Valley, Washington, USA.
Lycoris is currently part of Mandriva.

Lycoris Desktop/LX 
Lycoris Desktop/LX installer was originally based on Caldera International's OpenLinux Workstation 3.1 distribution with the rest of the distribution built from the kernel up. The desktop and applications looked a lot like Microsoft Windows XP, right down to the background image that shipped with the software.

References

Linux companies

In 2002, they changed their name to Lycoris, and in 2005, they were bought by another company called Mandriva.

Lycoris's main product was Lycoris Desktop/LX, a Linux distribution. They were based in Maple Valley, Washington, and Lycoris is now part of Mandriva.

Lycoris Desktop/LX
Lycoris Desktop/LX was based on another Linux distribution called Caldera International's OpenLinux Workstation 3.1. The desktop and applications looked like Microsoft Windows XP, even with the background image that came with the software.

samples.title: Amykos
samples.original_text:
In Greek mythology, Amykos (), Latinized as Amycus, was the king of the Bebryces, a mythical people in Bithynia.

Family 
Amycus was the son of Poseidon and the Bithynian nymph Melia.

Mythology 
Amycus was a doughty man but being a king he compelled strangers to box as a way of killing them. When the Argonauts passed through Bithynia, Amycus challenged the best man of the crew to a boxing match. Polydeuces undertook to box against him and killed him with a blow on the elbow.

When the Bebryces rush to avenge him, the chiefs snatched up their arms and put them to flight with great slaughter.

Bay/Port 

During ancient time the bay at modern Beykoz was called Amykos.

Notes

References 

 Apollodorus, The Library with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website.
Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica translated by Robert Cooper Seaton (1853-1915), R. C. Loeb Classical Library Volume 001. London, William Heinemann Ltd, 1912. Online version at the Topos Text Project.
 Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica. George W. Mooney. London. Longmans, Green. 1912. Greek text available at the Perseus Digital Library.
 Gaius Julius Hyginus, Fabulae from The Myths of Hyginus translated and edited by Mary Grant. University of Kansas Publications in Humanistic Studies. Online version at the Topos Text Project.
 The Orphic Argonautica, translated by Jason Colavito. © Copyright 2011. Online version at the Topos Text Project.

easy_general.text:
In Greek mythology, Amycus was the king of the Bebryces, a group of mythical people in a place called Bithynia.

Family
Amycus was the son of Poseidon and a woman named Melia, who was from Bithynia.

Mythology
Amycus was a strong and brave man, but he was also a cruel king. He would force strangers to fight in a boxing match in order to kill them. When a group of people called the Argonauts passed through Bithynia, Amycus challenged the best man in the crew to a boxing match. Polydeuces agreed to fight and killed Amycus with a blow to the elbow.

When the Bebryces tried to avenge Amycus's death, the leaders of the Bebryces quickly grabbed their weapons and drove them away, killing many of them.

Bay/Port
In ancient times, the bay near modern Beykoz was called Amykos.

Notes

References
Apollodorus, The Library, translated by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S., in 2 volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, England, 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version available at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text also available from the same website.
Apollonius Rhodius, Argonautica, translated by Robert Cooper Seaton (1853-1915), R. C. Loeb Classical Library Volume 001. London, William Heinemann Ltd, 1912. Online version available at the Topos Text Project.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, Amykos, also known as Amycus, was the king of the Bebryces, a group of mythical people in a place called Bithynia.

Family
Amycus was the son of Poseidon and a nymph named Melia from Bithynia.

Mythology
Amycus was a strong and brave man, but he was also a cruel king. He would force strangers to fight in a boxing match in order to kill them. When the Argonauts passed through Bithynia, Amycus challenged the strongest member of the crew to a boxing match. Polydeuces agreed to fight him and killed him with a powerful blow to the elbow.

When the Bebryces tried to avenge Amycus's death, the leaders of the Bebryces quickly grabbed their weapons and drove them away, killing many of them.

Bay/Port
In ancient times, the bay in modern Turkey called Beykoz was named after Amykos.

Notes
