easy_general.text: SI derived units are units of measurement that come from the seven basic units set by the International System of Units (SI). They can be dimensionless or made by multiplying or dividing the basic units. The SI has special names for 22 of these derived units, like the hertz for frequency, the square meter for area, and kilogram per cubic meter for density. The names of these units are written in lowercase, but the symbols for units named after people start with an uppercase letter.

adult_non_technical.text: The International System of Units (SI) is a set of units used to measure things around the world. It has seven basic units, called base units, which are used to create other units. These other units are called derived units. Some of these derived units have special names, like the hertz, which measures frequency. Others, like the square metre for area or the kilogram per cubic metre for density, just show how they are made from the base units. The names of these units are written in lowercase, but the symbols for units named after people start with a capital letter. There are 22 derived units, including two dimensionless units that have special names. Some other units, like the hour, litre, tonne, bar, and electronvolt, are not part of the SI system but are often used with it.

adult_technical.text:
SI derived units are units of measurement derived from the seven base units specified by the International System of Units (SI). They are either dimensionless or can be expressed as a product of one or more of the base units, possibly scaled by an appropriate power of exponentiation. 

The SI has special names for 22 of these derived units (for example, hertz, the SI unit of measurement of frequency), but the rest merely reflect their derivation: for example, the square metre (m2), the SI derived unit of area; and the kilogram per cubic metre (kg/m3 or kg⋅m−3), the SI derived unit of density. 

The names of SI derived units, when written in full, are always in lowercase. However, the symbols for units named after persons are written with an uppercase initial letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz", but the symbol for metre is "m".

Derived units with special names
The International System of Units assigns special names to 22 derived units, which includes two dimensionless derived units, the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

samples.title: Separate-channel signaling
samples.original_text:
Separate-channel signaling is a form of signaling in which the whole or a part of one or more channels in a multichannel system is used to provide for supervisory and control signals for the message traffic channels.  

The same channels, such as frequency bands or time slots, that are used for signaling are not used for message traffic.

See also

 Common-channel signaling

References

Telephony signals

easy_general.text: Separate-channel signaling is a way to send information in a phone system. It uses a different part of the system to send instructions and control signals. This way, the control information doesn't interfere with the actual conversation.

adult_non_technical.text: Separate-channel signaling is a way of sending information in a phone system that uses different channels for controlling the call and sending the actual message. This helps keep the system organized and efficient.

adult_technical.text:
Separate-channel signaling is a method used in multichannel systems to allocate one or more channels for supervisory and control signals related to message traffic channels. These channels, such as frequency bands or time slots, are not utilized for message traffic.

See also: Common-channel signaling

References: Telephony signals

samples.title: 1440s BC
samples.original_text:
The 1440s BC is a decade which lasted from 1449 BC to 1440 BC.

Events and trends
 1449 BC: Fíachu Labrainne, Milesians' High King of Ireland, is killed and succeeded by Eochu Mumu
 c. 1448 BC: The Gnbtyw people (Genebtyw or Genebtyu) first appear in Ganibatum during the 32nd year of reign of Thutmose III, the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt
1445–1444 BC: The Book of Leviticus is written.
 c. 1440 BC: first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar which controlled the Gulf of İzmir

References

easy_general.text:
The 1440s BC was a decade that lasted from 1449 BC to 1440 BC. During this time, some important things happened:

1. In 1449 BC, a man named Fíachu Labrainne, who was the leader of the Milesians in Ireland, was killed. Another man named Eochu Mumu took over as the new leader.
2. Around 1448 BC, a group of people called the Gnbtyw started to live in a place called Ganibatum. This was during the time of a powerful ruler named Thutmose III, who was the sixth Pharaoh of Egypt.
3. Between 1445 and 1444 BC, a book called the Book of Leviticus was written. This book is part of the Bible and has important teachings for Jewish people.
4. Around 1440 BC, the first big city was built near a mountain called Mount Yamanlar. This city controlled an area called the Gulf of İzmir.

References:

adult_non_technical.text:
The 1440s BC was a decade that lasted from 1449 BC to 1440 BC. During this time, several important events happened.

In 1449 BC, Fíachu Labrainne, the High King of Ireland, was killed and replaced by Eochu Mumu. Around 1448 BC, a group of people called the Genebtyw first appeared in a place called Ganibatum. This was during the reign of Thutmose III, who was the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt.

Between 1445 and 1444 BC, the Book of Leviticus was written. Around 1440 BC, the first recorded urban settlement was established on or near Mount Yamanlar, which controlled the Gulf of İzmir.

adult_technical.text:
The 1440s BC, encompassing from 1449 BC to 1440 BC, was a period of significant historical events and developments across various regions.

Key events and trends:
- 1449 BC: Fíachu Labrainne, the Milesians' High King of Ireland, is assassinated and succeeded by Eochu Mumu.
- c. 1448 BC: The Gnbtyw people, also known as Genebtyw or Genebtyu, make their first appearance in Ganibatum during the 32nd year of Thutmose III's reign, the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt.
- 1445–1444 BC: The Book of Leviticus is composed.
- c. 1440 BC: The first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar, which controlled the Gulf of İzmir, is established.

References:

samples.original_text:
Year 1308 (MCCCVIII) was a leap year starting on Monday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.

Events 
 January–December 
 January 25 – King Edward II of England marries Isabella of France. They are both crowned a month later (on February 25).
 March 8 – Póvoa de Varzim (then Varazim), Portugal gains a foral from Denis of Portugal.
 April 15 – Abu Hammu I ascends to the throne of the Kingdom of Tlemcen after the death of his brother Abu-I Zayyan.
 November 27 – Henry VII, King of Germany, is elected Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire.
 December 28 – Emperor Hanazono ascends to the throne of Japan.

 Date unknown 
 The Capet-Anjou family begins to rule Hungary.
 The Sultanate of Rûm ends.
 King Philip IV of France purchases the Hôtel de Nesle, and builds one of the earliest indoor tennis courts there.
 approx. date – Dante Alighieri begins to write the Divine Comedy.

Births 
 July 26 – Stefan Dušan, Emperor of the Serbs (d. 1355)
 date unknown
 Longchenpa, Tibetan Buddhist teacher (d. 1363)
 Laura de Noves, French countess (d. 1348)
 Prince Moriyoshi, Japanese shōgun (d. 1335)

Deaths 
 March 18 – Yuri I of Galicia
 April 5 – Ivan Kőszegi, Hungarian baron
 May 1 – Albert I of Germany, Duke of Austria (murdered) (b. 1255)
 September 4 – Margaret of Burgundy, Queen of Sicily (b. 1250)
 September 10 – Emperor Go-Nijō of Japan (b. 1285)
 October 10 – Patrick Dunbar, 8th Earl of Dunbar
 November 8 – Duns Scotus, Scottish philosopher

 date unknown
 Vakhtang III of Georgia (b. 1276)
 Andrea Morisco, Genoese pirate

easy_general.text:
In the year 1308, which was a leap year starting on a Monday, many important things happened. Here are some of the key events:

- January 25: King Edward II of England married Isabella of France. They were both crowned a month later on February 25.
- March 8: Póvoa de Varzim, Portugal, received a special document called a foral from King Denis of Portugal.
- April 15: Abu Hammu I became the ruler of the Kingdom of Tlemcen after his brother Abu-I Zayyan died.
- November 27: Henry VII, King of Germany, became the Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire.
- December 28: Emperor Hanazono became the ruler of Japan.

During this time, the Capet-Anjou family started ruling Hungary, and the Sultanate of Rûm ended. King Philip IV of France bought a place called the Hôtel de Nesle and built one of the first indoor tennis courts there. Dante Alighieri started writing a famous book called the Divine Comedy.

Many people were born during this year, including:

- July 26: Stefan Dušan, Emperor of the Serbs (d. 1355)
- Longchenpa, a Tibetan Buddhist teacher (d. 1363)
- Laura de Noves, a French countess (d. 1348)
- Prince Moriyoshi, a Japanese shōgun (d. 1335)

Some important people died during this year, including:

- March 18: Yuri I of Galicia
- April 5: Ivan Kőszegi, a Hungarian baron
- May 1: Albert I of Germany, Duke of Austria (murdered)
- September 4: Margaret of Burgundy, Queen of Sicily
- September 10: Emperor Go-Nijō of Japan
- October 10: Patrick Dunbar, 8th Earl of Dunbar
- November 8: Duns Scotus, a Scottish philosopher
- December 16: Emperor Tran Nhan Tong of Vietnam
- December 21: Henry I, Landgrave of Hesse
- Vakhtang III of Georgia
- Andrea Morisco, a Genoese pirate

adult_technical.text:
The year 1308, a leap year commencing on a Monday, marked several pivotal events in the Julian calendar. On January 25, King Edward II of England married Isabella of France, and they were both crowned a month later on February 25. In March, Póvoa de Varzim, then known as Varazim, received a foral from King Denis of Portugal. On April 15, Abu Hammu I ascended to the throne of the Kingdom of Tlemcen following the death of his brother, Abu-I Zayyan. On July 26, Stefan Dušan, Emperor of the Serbs, was born. At an unknown date, Longchenpa, a prominent Tibetan Buddhist teacher, was born. Laura de Noves, a French countess, passed away in 1348. Prince Moriyoshi, a Japanese shōgun, died in 1335.

In March, Yuri I of Galicia passed away. On April 5, Ivan Kőszegi, a Hungarian baron, died. On May 1, Albert I of Germany, Duke of Austria, was murdered. On September 4, Margaret of Burgundy, Queen of Sicily, passed away. On September 10, Emperor Go-Nijō of Japan died. On October 10, Patrick Dunbar, 8th Earl of Dunbar, passed away. On November 8, Duns Scotus, a Scottish philosopher, died. On December 16, Emperor Tran Nhan Tong of Vietnam passed away. On December 21, Henry I, Landgrave of Hesse, died. At an unknown date, Vakhtang III of Georgia, born in 1276, passed away. Andrea Morisco, a Genoese pirate, also died during this time.

Pasteur may also refer to:

easy_general.text:
Louis Pasteur was a French chemist and microbiologist who lived from 1822 to 1895. He is famous for his work on germs and how they can make us sick. Because of his work and discoveries, the name "Pasteur" is used in many different places around the world.

You can find Pasteur Island and Pasteur Peninsula in Antarctica, which is a cold place at the bottom of the Earth. There is also a river in Quebec, Canada, and a street in Tehran, Iran, named after him.

In space, there is a crater on the moon and a crater on Mars named after him. There is also an asteroid called 4804 Pasteur, which is a big rock in space.

On Earth, you can find a train station in Buenos Aires, Argentina, in Paris, France, and in Milan, Italy, all called Pasteur.

Pasteur is also the name of a 1935 French movie, a ship that sank in 1971, and a big ship built in 1938. There is a museum in Paris called the Pasteur Museum, and a university in Strasbourg called the Louis Pasteur University. There is also a building called the Pasteur Island in Monaco.

There are many other things named after Louis Pasteur, like the Pasteur effect, the Pasteur pipette, and the Pasteur point, which is a level of oxygen.

adult_non_technical.text:

samples.original_text:
Eagle Point Township is a township in Marshall County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 33 at the 2000 census.

Eagle Point Township was organized in 1890, and named for an eagle's nest in a nearby grove.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  is land and  (1.52%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 33 people, 13 households, and 10 families residing in the township. The population density was 1.2 people per square mile (0.5/km2). There were 18 housing units at an average density of 0.6/sq mi (0.2/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 13 households, out of which 30.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 76.9% were married couples living together, 7.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 15.4% were non-families. 15.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 7.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.54 and the average family size was 2.82.

In the township the population was spread out, with 15.2% under the age of 18, 18.2% from 18 to 24, 30.3% from 25 to 44, 15.2% from 45 to 64, and 21.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 120.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 115.4 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $40,000, and the median income for a family was $45,833. Males had a median income of $22,500 versus $23,750 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,069. There were 20.0% of families and 20.7% of the population living below the poverty line, including 50.0% of under eighteens and none of those over 64.

samples.original_text:
Year 834 (DCCCXXXIV) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.

Events 
 By place 
 Europe 
 March 1 – Emperor Louis the Pious is restored as sole ruler of the Frankish Empire. After his re-accession to the throne, his eldest son Lothair I flees to Burgundy.
 Danish Vikings raid the trading settlement of Dorestad (present-day Wijk bij Duurstede), located in the south-east of the province of Utrecht (modern Netherlands).
 Summer – The Viking ship of Oseberg near Tønsberg (modern Norway) is buried in a mound, during the Viking Age (approximate date).
 The first mention is made of the Jona River ('the cold one') in Switzerland (approximate date).

 Britain 
 King Óengus II dies after a 14-year reign. He is succeeded by his nephew Drest IX, as ruler of the Picts.

 By topic 
 Religion 
 July 20 – Ansegisus, Frankish abbot and advisor of former emperor Charlemagne, dies at Fontenelle Abbey in Normandy (or 833).

Births 
 Aud the Deep-Minded, Icelandic queen
 Euthymius I, Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople (d. 917)
 Lady Shuiqiu, wife of Qian Kuan (d. 901)
 Mo Xuanqing, Chinese scholar
 Pi Rixiu, Chinese poet (approximate date)
 Robert, Frankish nobleman (d. 866)
 Tan Quanbo, Chinese warlord (d. 918)

Deaths 
 July 20 or 833 – Ansegisus, Frankish abbot 
 Adelchis I, duke of Spoleto (Italy)
 Cellach mac Brain, king of Leinster (Ireland)
 Fridugisus, Anglo-Saxon abbot (approximate date)
 Gaucelm, Frankish nobleman
 Nasr ibn 'Abdallah, Muslim governor
 Odo I, Frankish nobleman
 Óengus II, king of the Picts
 Robert III, Frankish nobleman (b. 800)
 Wang Chengyuan, Chinese general (b. 801)
 Wang Tingcou, general of the Tang Dynasty
 William, Frankish nobleman

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 834, which was a common year starting on a Thursday, several events happened in Europe and Britain.

In Europe, on March 1, Emperor Louis the Pious was restored as the sole ruler of the Frankish Empire. After this, his eldest son, Lothair I, fled to Burgundy. Danish Vikings attacked a trading settlement called Dorestad, which is now called Wijk bij Duurstede, in the Netherlands. During the summer, a Viking ship was buried in a mound near Tønsberg, Norway, during the Viking Age. The first mention of the Jona River, also known as "the cold one," was made in Switzerland.

In Britain, King Óengus II died after a 14-year reign and was succeeded by his nephew, Drest IX, as the ruler of the Picts.

On July 20, Ansegisus, a Frankish abbot and advisor to former emperor Charlemagne, died at Fontenelle Abbey in Normandy. He might have died in 833 instead.

Some important people were born in 834, including Aud the Deep-Minded, an Icelandic queen, Euthymius I, the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople, Lady Shuiqiu, the wife of Qian Kuan, Mo Xuanqing, a Chinese scholar, Pi Rixiu, a Chinese poet, Robert, a Frankish nobleman, and Tan Quanbo, a Chinese warlord.

On July 20 or 833, several notable people died, including Ansegisus, a Frankish abbot, Adelchis I, the duke of Spoleto in Italy, Cellach mac Brain, the king of Leinster in Ireland, Fridugisus, an Anglo-Saxon abbot, Gaucelm, a Frankish nobleman, Nasr ibn 'Abdallah, a Muslim governor, Odo I, a Frankish nobleman, Óengus II, the king of the Picts, Robert III, a Frankish nobleman, Wang Chengyuan, a Chinese general, Wang Tingcou, a general of the Tang Dynasty, and William, a Frankish nobleman.

References

During the summer, a Viking ship near Tønsberg, Norway, was buried in a mound, marking the beginning of the Viking Age. The first mention of the Jona River, known as "the cold one," was made in Switzerland.

In Britain, King Óengus II died after 14 years of rule and was succeeded by his nephew, Drest IX, as ruler of the Picts.

In the realm of religion, Ansegisus, a Frankish abbot and advisor to Charlemagne, passed away at Fontenelle Abbey in Normandy on July 20 or in 833.

samples.title: Bashaw, Wisconsin
samples.original_text:
Bashaw is a town in Washburn County, Wisconsin, United States. The population was 921 at the 2000 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of 33.9 square miles (87.8 km), of which, 33.5 square miles (86.8 km) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.0 km) of it (1.09%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 921 people, 339 households, and 267 families residing in the town.  The population density was 27.5 people per square mile (10.6/km).  There were 387 housing units at an average density of 11.5 per square mile (4.5/km).  The racial makeup of the town was 98.15% White, 0.22% African American, 0.11% Native American, 0.43% Asian, and 1.09% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.43% of the population.

There were 339 households, out of which 34.2% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 73.5% were married couples living together, 3.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.2% were non-families. 17.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 6.8% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.72 and the average family size was 3.10.

In the town, the population was spread out, with 27.1% under the age of 18, 6.5% from 18 to 24, 27.4% from 25 to 44, 25.6% from 45 to 64, and 13.4% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 105.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 106.5 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $43,500, and the median income for a family was $47,014. Males had a median income of $31,923 versus $21,667 for females. The per capita income for the town was $16,982.  About 7.5% of families and 8.8% of the population were below the poverty line, including 10.2% of those under age 18 and 13.7% of those age 65 or over.

Topography: Kapelle is a flat area with some hills and valleys.

Transport: There is a train station called Kapelle-Biezelinge where people can take trains.

Famous People: From Kapelle, there was a writer named Annie M.G. Schmidt who helped create famous Dutch songs. A poet named Jan Elburg was from Wemeldinge, and a politician from Kapelle named Jan Peter Balkenende was the Prime Minister of the Netherlands for a long time. Jan Kees de Jager, also from Kapelle, was a politician who was in charge of money for the Netherlands.

Tell Township is a township in Huntingdon County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 662 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 42.5 square miles (110.2 km), all of it land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 648 people, 238 households, and 179 families residing in the township.  The population density was 15.2 people per square mile (5.9/km).  There were 343 housing units at an average density of 8.1/sq mi (3.1/km).  The racial make-up of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 238 households, out of which 36.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 64.3% were married couples living together, 7.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.4% were non-families. 23.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.70 and the average family size was 3.17.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.9% under the age of 18, 8.8% from 18 to 24, 30.2% from 25 to 44, 21.5% from 45 to 64, and 13.6% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 98.8 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 100.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $32,679, and the median income for a family was $39,444. Males had a median income of $34,444 versus $19,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,832.  About 3.9% of families and 8.5% of the population were below the poverty line, including 13.9% of those under age 18 and 9.0% of those age 65 or over.

samples.original_text:
Year 265 (CCLXV) was a common year starting on Sunday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus (or, less frequently, year 1018 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 265 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Empire 
 Emperor Gallienus tries twice to crush the usurper Postumus, but on the first occasion Aureolus, commander of the elite cavalry, carelessly lets him escape. The second time, Gallienus sustains an arrow wound and has to break off his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus has holed up. He makes no other serious attempt to overcome his rival, instead devoting his attention to the political and military problems in the Danube and eastern parts of the Roman Empire.  
 Postumus makes no move to march on Rome and claim his territory south of Gaul. 
 Gallienus gives the order to fortify Milan and Verona. 
 Gallienus repels the invasion of the Goths in the Balkans. 
 A general of Gallienus' army, Victorinus, defects to Postumus.

 China  
 Sima Zhao, who had been the regent and de facto primary authority of the state of Cao Wei for little over 10 years by this point, passes away, leaving his authority to his eldest son, Sima Yan, who will go on to disestablish the state of Cao Wei in 266, founding the Jin dynasty.

Births 
 Eusebius of Caesarea, Greek historian (approximate date)

Deaths 
 September 6 – Sima Zhao, Chinese general and politician (b. 211)
 Ma Jun, Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot
 Zhu (or Jing), Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 265, which was a common year starting on a Sunday, important events happened in the Roman Empire and China.

In the Roman Empire, Emperor Gallienus tried to stop a man named Postumus from trying to take control. However, Postumus escaped both times, and Gallienus had to give up trying to stop him. Instead, Gallienus focused on other problems in the empire, like the Goths invading the Balkans. 

In China, a powerful leader named Sima Zhao died, leaving control of the state of Cao Wei to his son, Sima Yan. Sima Yan would later start a new dynasty called the Jin dynasty.

During this year, a Greek historian named Eusebius of Caesarea was born, and three important Chinese figures, Sima Zhao, Ma Jun, and Zhu (or Jing), passed away.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 265, which was a common year in the Julian calendar, several significant events took place. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus, or less commonly as 1018 from the founding year of the city of Rome. The number 265 has been used to identify this year since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar became the standard in Europe.

In the Roman Empire, Emperor Gallienus tried to defeat a rival named Postumus twice. In the first attempt, Aureolus, the commander of the elite cavalry, let Postumus escape. In the second attempt, Gallienus was injured and had to stop the attack. After that, Gallienus focused on other political and military issues in the Danube and eastern parts of the empire. Postumus did not try to take over Rome or the territory south of Gaul.

Gallienus also ordered the fortification of Milan and Verona. He successfully fought off a Goths invasion in the Balkans. One of his own generals, Victorinus, joined Postumus.

In China, Sima Zhao, who had been the main leader of the state of Cao Wei for over 10 years, passed away. He left his authority to his eldest son, Sima Yan, who would later establish the Jin dynasty in 266.

During this year, Eusebius of Caesarea, a Greek historian, was born. On September 6th, Sima Zhao, a Chinese general and politician, died. Ma Jun, a Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot, also passed away. Zhu, an empress of the Eastern Wu state, died as well.

adult_technical.text:
Year 265 (CCLXV) was a common year starting on Sunday of the Julian calendar. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus (or, less frequently, year 1018 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 265 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

By place

Roman Empire
Emperor Gallienus attempted to defeat the usurper Postumus twice. On the first occasion, Aureolus, commander of the elite cavalry, allowed Postumus to escape. The second time, Gallienus sustained an arrow wound and had to abandon his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus was hiding. Gallienus made no further attempts to overcome his rival, instead focusing on the political and military challenges in the Danube and eastern parts of the Roman Empire.

Postumus made no move to march on Rome and claim his territory south of Gaul.

Gallienus ordered the fortification of Milan and Verona.

Gallienus successfully repelled the invasion of the Goths in the Balkans.

A general in Gallienus' army, Victorinus, defected to Postumus.

China
Sima Zhao, who had been the regent and de facto primary authority of the state of Cao Wei for over 10 years, passed away. He left his authority to his eldest son, Sima Yan, who would later disintegrate the state of Cao Wei in 266 and found the Jin dynasty.

Births
Eusebius of Caesarea, Greek historian (approximate date)

Deaths
September 6 – Sima Zhao, Chinese general and politician (b. 211)
Ma Jun, Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot
Zhu (or Jing), Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state

References

samples.title: Bedrock Records
samples.original_text:
Bedrock Records is an English record label for trance, progressive house and techno started by Nick Muir and John Digweed. Its name comes from a long running and successful club night held in Hastings and also at Heaven nightclub, London - both also called Bedrock. Bedrock Records has released many singles from artists such as Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars and Jerry Bonham.  Bedrock is also the name that Digweed and Muir use as their production moniker.

Bedrock has had different imprints: Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock and Black (Bedrock). Currently it has Bedrock Digital and one called Lost & Found belonging to Guy J.

The first Bedrock album compiled and mixed by John Digweed was released in 1999, containing several tracks signed to the Bedrock label. 

In 2018, Digweed marked the 20th anniversary of the label with the release of Bedrock XX.

See also 
 List of electronic music record labels

References

External links
Official site

Trance record labels
House music record labels
Techno record labels

easy_general.text:
Bedrock Records is a British record label that started with trance, progressive house, and techno music. It was created by Nick Muir and John Digweed. The name comes from a popular club night in Hastings and London, also called Bedrock.

Bedrock Records has released many songs by famous artists like Astro, Glyde, Brancaccio, Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars, and Jerry Bonham. Bedrock is also the name Digweed and Muir use when they make music together.

Bedrock has had different parts, like Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock, and Black (Bedrock). Now, it has Bedrock Digital and Lost & Found, which belongs to Guy J.

The first Bedrock album was made by John Digweed and released in 1999. It had many songs from the Bedrock label.

In 2018, John Digweed celebrated the 20th anniversary of Bedrock Records by releasing an album called Bedrock XX.

For more information, you can check out a list of electronic music record labels or the official website of Bedrock Records.

adult_technical.text:
Bedrock Records is an English record label specializing in trance, progressive house, and techno, founded by Nick Muir and John Digweed. The label's name is derived from a long-standing and successful club night held in Hastings and at the Heaven nightclub in London, both known as Bedrock. Over the years, Bedrock Records has released numerous singles from various artists, including Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars, and Jerry Bonham. Additionally, Bedrock is the production moniker used by both Digweed and Muir.

Bedrock Records has had several imprints throughout its history, including Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock, and Black (Bedrock). Currently, the label operates Bedrock Digital and Lost & Found, an imprint owned by Guy J.

In 1999, John Digweed compiled and mixed the first Bedrock album, which featured several tracks signed to the Bedrock label. In 2018, Digweed celebrated the label's 20th anniversary with the release of Bedrock XX.

samples.title: Hippomedon
samples.original_text:
Hippomedon (; Ἰππομέδων, gen.: Ἰππομέδοντος) may refer to several figures in Greek mythology:

 Hippomedon, one of the Seven against Thebes.
 Hippomedon, father of Ereuthalion.
Hippomedon, son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe, a defender of Troy killed by Neoptolemus.
Hippomedon, father of Menoites. His son was another defender of Troy and was killed by Teucer.

Notes

References 

 Apollodorus, The Library with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website.
 Quintus Smyrnaeus, The Fall of Troy translated by Way. A. S. Loeb Classical Library Volume 19. London: William Heinemann, 1913. Online version at theio.com
 Quintus Smyrnaeus, The Fall of Troy. Arthur S. Way. London: William Heinemann; New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. 1913. Greek text available at the Perseus Digital Library.

easy_general.text: Hippomedon is a name that refers to several characters in Greek mythology. One of them was part of the Seven against Thebes, a group of warriors who fought against the city of Thebes. Another Hippomedon was the father of Ereuthalion, who was also a warrior. A third Hippomedon was a defender of Troy and was killed by Neoptolemus. The last Hippomedon was the father of Menoites, who was another defender of Troy and was killed by Teucer.

adult_non_technical.text:
Hippomedon is a name that refers to several characters in Greek mythology. Here are some of them:

1. Hippomedon, one of the Seven against Thebes, a group of warriors who fought against the city of Thebes.
2. Hippomedon, the father of Ereuthalion, another warrior from Thebes.
3. Hippomedon, the son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe, a defender of Troy who was killed by Neoptolemus.
4. Hippomedon, the father of Menoites, whose son was another defender of Troy and was killed by Teucer.

These characters are part of the rich world of Greek mythology.

adult_technical.text:
Hippomedon is a name associated with several figures in Greek mythology, each with their own unique characteristics and roles. Here are the different instances:

1. Hippomedon, one of the Seven against Thebes: This Hippomedon was a member of the group of seven warriors who fought against Thebes during the Seven Against Thebes war. This Hippomedon is not related to the other figures with the same name.

2. Hippomedon, father of Ereuthalion: This Hippomedon was the father of Ereuthalion, who was a member of the Seven Against Thebes. This Hippomedon is not related to the other figures with the same name.

3. Hippomedon, son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe: This Hippomedon was a defender of Troy during the Trojan War and was killed by Neoptolemus. This Hippomedon is not related to the other figures with the same name.

4. Hippomedon, father of Menoites: This Hippomedon was the father of Menoites, who was another defender of Troy during the Trojan War and was killed by Teucer. This Hippomedon is not related to the other figures with the same name.

samples.title: Blackwood National Park
samples.original_text:
Blackwood is a national park in the Charters Towers Region, Queensland, Australia.

Geography 
The park is west of Mount Coolon in North Queensland, 924 km northwest of Brisbane.  It is named after the Australian Blackwood tree species.

The parks is accessible via the Gregory Developmental Road.  Blackwood was created to protect Brigalow Belt plant communities and includes landscapes of rugged hills and gorges, stony ridges and alluvial flats.

About 80 species of birds have been recorded in the park.

Restrictions 
Camping and fires are not permitted within the park.

See also

 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of Queensland
Protected areas established in 1991
North Queensland
1991 establishments in Australia

easy_general.text:
Blackwood National Park is a beautiful place in Queensland, Australia. It's located near a town called Mount Coolon, about 924 kilometers northwest of Brisbane. The park is named after a type of tree called the Australian Blackwood.

You can visit the park by driving on a road called the Gregory Developmental Road. The park was made to protect special plant communities called Brigalow Belt. It has landscapes like rugged hills, gorges, stony ridges, and flat areas.

About 80 different types of birds live in the park. However, camping and making fires are not allowed in the park.

adult_non_technical.text: Blackwood National Park is a beautiful place located in the Charters Towers Region of Queensland, Australia. It's named after the Blackwood tree, a type of tree that grows there. The park is accessible by the Gregory Developmental Road and is home to about 80 different types of birds. However, camping and fires are not allowed in the park to protect its natural beauty and wildlife.

adult_technical.text:
Blackwood National Park is situated in the Charters Towers Region of Queensland, Australia. It is located near Mount Coolon, approximately 924 kilometers northwest of Brisbane. The park is named after the Australian Blackwood tree species and is accessible via the Gregory Developmental Road.

Blackwood National Park was established to safeguard the plant communities of Brigalow Belt. The park features diverse landscapes including rugged hills, gorges, stony ridges, and alluvial flats. Over 80 species of birds have been documented within the park.

Camping and fires are prohibited within the park.

See also: Protected areas of Queensland

References: National parks of Queensland, Protected areas established in 1991, North Queensland, 1991 establishments in Australia

samples.title: Multiple homing
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, the term multiple homing has the following meanings: 
 telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility so that it can be served by one or several switching centers. Multiple homing may use a single directory number. 
 In telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility to more than one switching center by separate access lines. Separate directory numbers are applicable to each switching center accessed. 

 In military, such as Missiles and loitering munitions, it is ability of a single weapon system or projectile to select, focus and simultaneously engage multiple targets.

See also
 Homing pigeon
 Infrared homing
 Missile guidance

References

Communication circuits
Military terminology

easy_general.text:
In telecommunications, the term "multiple homing" has two main meanings:

1. In telephone systems, it means connecting a phone or other device to multiple switching centers, so it can be served by different centers. This can be done using a single phone number.

2. In military, it refers to the ability of a single weapon system or projectile to target and attack multiple enemies at the same time.

For example, a homing pigeon can find its way back to its nest, and a missile can track and hit multiple targets at once. This is called multiple homing.

You can learn more about topics like homing pigeons, infrared homing, and missile guidance.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the world of communication, the term "multiple homing" has a couple of different meanings. 

First, in phone systems, it means that a phone line can be connected to multiple switching centers. This means that the same line can be used by different switching centers, and you can use the same phone number for all of them. It's like having one phone line that can be used by different people in different places.

Second, in phone systems, it also means that a phone line can be connected to multiple switching centers using separate phone lines. In this case, each switching center has its own phone number. It's like having multiple phone lines for different switching centers.

Third, in the military, it means that a single weapon system or projectile can target and attack multiple enemies at the same time. It's like having one weapon that can hit multiple targets at once.

adult_technical.text: In telecommunication, the term "multiple homing" refers to the connection of a terminal facility to multiple switching centers. This can be achieved using a single directory number or separate directory numbers for each switching center. In military applications, such as missiles and loitering munitions, multiple homing refers to the ability of a single weapon system or projectile to select, focus, and simultaneously engage multiple targets.

samples.title: Prado Verde, Texas
samples.original_text:
Prado Verde is a census-designated place (CDP) in El Paso County, Texas, United States. The population is 246 according to the 2010 census. It is part of the El Paso Metropolitan Statistical Area. The ZIP Code encompassing the CDP area is 79932.

Geography
Prado Verde is located at  (31.890005, -106.613181).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 200 people, 60 households, and 55 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,557.7 people per square mile (594.0/km2). There were 62 housing units at an average density of 482.9/sq mi (184.1/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.00% White, 0.50% Native American, and 1.50% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 55.00% of the population.

There were 60 households, out of which 51.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 85.0% were married couples living together, 3.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 8.3% were non-families. 8.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 1.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.33 and the average family size was 3.51.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 35.0% under the age of 18, 6.5% from 18 to 24, 26.5% from 25 to 44, 24.5% from 45 to 64, and 7.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 119.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.0 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $49,286, and the median income for a family was $68,056. Males had a median income of $38,409 versus $45,179 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $14,186. None of the families and 3.9% of the population were living below the poverty line.

References

Census-designated places in El Paso County, Texas

samples.title: Fionnuala
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Finnguala (modern spellings: Fionnghuala,  Fionnuala , or  Finola; literally  meaning "white shoulder") was the daughter of Lir of the Tuatha Dé Danann. In the legend of the Children of Lir, she was changed into a swan and cursed by her stepmother, Aoife, to wander the lakes and rivers of Ireland, with her brothers Fiachra, Conn and Aodh, for 900 years until saved by the marriage of Lairgren, son of Colman, son of Cobthach, and Deoch, daughter of Finghin, whose union broke the curse. 'The Song of Fionnuala', with lyrics by Thomas Moore speaks of her wanderings.

The name is anglicized as Fenella. The shortened version Nuala is commonly used as a first name in contemporary Ireland.

In Irish mythology, there is a character named Fionnuala, whose name means "white shoulder." She was the daughter of Lir from the Tuatha Dé Danann, a group of mythical beings. In the story of the Children of Lir, Fionnuala was turned into a swan by her stepmother, Aoife, and cursed to wander the lakes and rivers of Ireland for 900 years with her brothers, Fiachra, Conn, and Aodh. However, the curse was broken when Lairgren and Deoch got married. A song called "The Song of Fionnuala" by Thomas Moore talks about her journey.

The name Fionnuala is sometimes anglicized as Fenella, and its shortened version, Nuala, is a popular first name in modern Ireland. Some famous people with this name include Fionnuala Boyd, Fionnuala Carr, and Fionnuala Kenny.

adult_technical.text:
In Irish mythology, Fionnghuala, also known as Fionnuala or Finola, was the daughter of Lir of the Tuatha Dé Danann. Her name literally translates to "white shoulder." In the legend of the Children of Lir, Fionnghuala was transformed into a swan and cursed by her stepmother, Aoife, to wander the lakes and rivers of Ireland with her brothers Fiachra, Conn, and Aodh for 900 years. The curse was broken by the union of Lairgren, son of Colman, son of Cobthach, and Deoch, daughter of Finghin. "The Song of Fionnuala," written by Thomas Moore, describes her wanderings.

The name Fionnghuala is anglicized as Fenella, and the shortened version Nuala is commonly used as a first name in contemporary Ireland.

People with the given name Fionnghuala include Fionnuala Boyd, Fionnuala Carr, Fionnuala Ellwood, Fionnuala Kenny, Fionnuala McCormack, Fionnuala Ní Aoláin, Fionnuala Ní Fhlatharta, Fionnuala Ní Flaithbheartaigh, Fionnuala Sherry, and Fionnuala Sweeney.

People with the given name Fionnula include Fionnula Flanagan.

samples.title: Sluis-Aardenburg
samples.original_text:
Sluis-Aardenburg was a municipality in the province of Zeeland, in the south-western part of the Netherlands. It was created from a merger of Sluis and Aardenburg in 1995, and it merged with the municipality of Oostburg, on 1 January 2003, to form the new municipality of Sluis.  Sluis-Aardenburg covered an area of 83.48 km², of which 0.89 km² was water.

The municipality comprised the following towns, villages and townships:
Aardenburg
Draaiburg
Eede
Heille
Retranchement
Sint Anna ter Muiden
Sint Kruis
Sluis
Terhofstede
Zwindorp

In 2003, it merged with another place called Oostburg to become a new place called Sluis. Sluis-Aardenburg was quite big, covering an area of 83.48 square kilometers, with only 0.89 square kilometers being water.

Within this place, there were several towns, villages, and townships: Aardenburg, Draaiburg, Eede, Heille, Retranchement, Sint Anna ter Muiden, Sint Kruis, Sluis, Terhofstede, and Zwindorp.

adult_technical.text:
Sluis-Aardenburg was a former municipality located in the province of Zeeland, situated in the south-western part of the Netherlands. It was established through the merger of the municipalities of Sluis and Aardenburg in 1995. Subsequently, this municipality merged with Oostburg on January 1, 2003, to form the new municipality of Sluis. The total area of Sluis-Aardenburg was 83.48 square kilometers, with 0.89 square kilometers being covered by water.

The municipality of Sluis-Aardenburg included the following towns, villages, and townships: Aardenburg, Draaiburg, Eede, Heille, Retranchement, Sint Anna ter Muiden, Sint Kruis, Sluis, Terhofstede, and Zwindorp.

samples.title: Appendix
samples.original_text:
Appendix may refer to:

In documents
Addendum, an addition made to a document by its author after its initial printing or publication
Bibliography, a systematic list of books and other works
Index (publishing), a list of words or phrases with pointers to where related material can be found in a document

Anatomy
Appendix (anatomy), a part of the human digestive system
Appendix of the epididymis, a detached efferent duct of the epididymis
Appendix testis, a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct
Epiploic appendix, one of several small pouches of fat on the peritoneum along the colon and rectum
Appendix of the laryngeal ventricle, a sac that extends from the laryngeal ventricle
Mesoappendix, the portion of the mesentery that connects the ileum to the vermiform appendix

Arts and media
Appendix (band), a Finnish punk rock group
The Appendix, a quarterly journal of history and culture

See also
 Appendicitis

easy_general.text:
"An 'appendix' can mean different things depending on the context.

In documents, an addendum is an extra part added to a document after it's been published. A bibliography is a list of books and other works used in a document. An index is a list of words or phrases that helps you find related information in a document.

In anatomy, the appendix is a part of the human digestive system. It's a small, tube-like organ attached to the large intestine. It can get infected and cause appendicitis.

In arts and media, the appendix can also refer to a Finnish punk rock band or a quarterly journal about history and culture."

adult_non_technical.text:
"An appendix is a term that can refer to different things, depending on the context. Here are a few examples:

In documents:
An addendum is an addition made to a document by its author after it has been initially printed or published.
A bibliography is a systematic list of books and other works that have been used or referenced in writing a document.
An index is a list of words or phrases with pointers to where related material can be found in a document.

In anatomy:
The appendix is a part of the human digestive system. It is a small, tube-shaped organ attached to the large intestine. It is also known as the vermiform appendix.
The appendix of the epididymis is a detached efferent duct of the epididymis.
The appendix testis is a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct.
The epiploic appendix is one of several small pouches of fat on the peritoneum, which is the lining of the abdominal cavity, along the colon.
The appendix of the laryngeal ventricle is a sac that extends from the laryngeal ventricle.
The mesoappendix is the portion of the mesentery that connects the ileum to the vermiform appendix.

In arts and media:
Appendix is a Finnish punk rock group.
The Appendix is a quarterly journal of history and culture.

See also: Appendicitis"

adult_technical.text:
The term "appendix" can refer to various entities depending on the context. In documents, it may refer to an addendum, which is an addition made to a document by its author after its initial printing or publication. Alternatively, it could refer to a bibliography, a systematic list of books and other works, or an index, a list of words or phrases with pointers to where related material can be found in a document.

In anatomy, the term "appendix" can refer to several parts of the human body. The most common reference is to the vermiform appendix, a part of the human digestive system. Additionally, it may refer to the appendix of the epididymis, a detached efferent duct of the epididymis, or the appendix testis, a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct. The epiploic appendix is one of several small pouches of fat on the peritoneum along the colon and rectum. The appendix of the laryngeal ventricle is a sac that extends from the laryngeal ventricle. The mesoappendix is the portion of the mesentery that connects the ileum to the vermiform appendix.

In the arts and media, the term "appendix" may refer to a Finnish punk rock group, The Appendix, or a quarterly journal of history and culture, also The Appendix.

See also: Appendicitis
